The miser then said to the king:
Let NÄgasena come with ten monks.
When the king heard the miser's words, he became greatly angry with the miser:
You are truly a miser without compare.
Your name is Miser, yet you begrudge the king's things as if they were your own.
You do not know how to go against my wishes, and there will be the crime of punishment.
The king said:
Go, I pardon your crime. Now that I am king, can I not bear to feed the monks?
The miser then felt ashamed and did not dare speak again.
Dhammika then went to where NÄgasena was and bowed, saying:
The great king invites NÄgasena.
NÄgasena said:
How many monks should the king allow me to go with?
Dhammika said:
From now on, how many Å›ramaá¹‡as do you wish to go with?
NÄgasena then went with eighty Å›ramaá¹‡as including Yavhala.
Dhammika and his group all went together, and in the morning they wanted to enter the city.
Dhammika and his group asked NÄgasena on the way:
Yesterday you said in front of the king that there is no self, why is it so?
NÄgasena asked Dhammika and his group:
What do you think is the self?
Dhammika and his group said:
I take the breath coming in and out as the self.
NÄgasena asked Dhammika and his group:
When a person's breath goes out and does not come back in, will that person still live?
Dhammika and his group said:
If the breath goes out and does not return, it will definitely be death.
NÄgasena said:
It is like a person blowing a flute, when the breath goes out and does not return,
Is it possible for the breath to come out and then return to the body again?
Dhammika looked at the crowd and said:
It cannot return.
Is it possible for the breath to come out and then return to the body again?
Dhammika looked at the crowd and said:
It cannot return.
Nagasena said:
The breath comes out and does not return, why then does a person not die?
Dhammika looked at the crowd and said:
I cannot understand the matter of breathing, please explain it to us.
Nagasena said:
The breath is a matter of the body.
If a person has thoughts, the tongue speaks, this is a matter of the tongue;
If the mind has doubts, the heart thinks about it, this is a matter of the heart.
Each has its own master.
If one observes and distinguishes them, they are all empty, there is no Nagasena.
Then, with a hopeful mind, he opened up and understood, and immediately accepted the five precepts to become an upÄsaka.
NÄgasena then went forward into the palace and ascended to the king's hall. The king immediately bowed to NÄgasena and stepped back.
NÄgasena then sat down, and the eighty Å›ramaá¹‡as all sat together.ğŸ”½The king prepared delicious food and drink, and with his own hands, he served NÄgasena and the assembly of Å›ramaá¹‡as.

After the meal was finished and they had washed their hands, the king gave each of the Å›ramaá¹‡as a set of robes and sandals, and he gave NÄgasena and YÄsa each three sets of robes and a set of sandals.
The king said to NÄgasena and YÄsa:
Keep ten people to stay, and send the rest away.
NÄgasena then sent the other Å›ramaá¹‡as away and kept ten people to stay together.
The king ordered the noble ladies and courtesans in the inner palace:ğŸ”½You should all go and serve the Å›ramaá¹‡as.
All of you, listen to me and to NÄgasena's discussion of the scriptures from within the curtains of the palace.
At that time, the noblemen, courtesans, and women all came out from within the curtains of the palace to listen to NÄgasena's discourse on the scriptures.
At that time, the king held a seat in front of NÄgasena and said:
What should be discussed?
NÄgasena said:
If the king wishes to hear the essentials, I shall discuss the essentials.
The king said:
What is the most essential thing for you monks?
Why do you become monks?
NÄgasena said:
We wish to abandon the hardships of this world and do not wish to suffer again in the next world. For this reason, we become monks.
This is the most essential and good for us.
The king said:
Do all monks become monks because they do not wish to suffer in this world and the next?
NÄgasena said:
Not all become monks for this reason.
There are four types of monks.
The king said:
What are the four?
NÄgasena said:

Some become monks because they owe debts, some become monks because they fear the county government, some become monks because they are poor, and some truly wish to abandon the suffering of this world and the next life and therefore become monks.
NÄgasena said:
I originally became a monk because I sincerely sought the Way.
The king said:
Do you now become a monk for the sake of the Way?
NÄgasena said:
I became a monk when I was young.
There were Buddhist scriptures and disciples, and the monks were all very wise.
I studied the scriptures and precepts from them and entered my heart. For this reason, I abandoned the suffering of this world and the next life and therefore became a monk.
The king said:
Excellent!
The king asked:
Is there anyone who dies and is not reborn again?
NÄgasena said:ğŸ”½Yes, there is.
Some intermediate beings are reborn in the next world, while others are not reborn.
The king said:
Who is reborn in the next world?
Who is not reborn?
NÄgasena said:
People who have affection, desire, and greed will be reborn in the next world;
People who are free from affection, desire, and greed will not be reborn in the next world.
The king said:
Is it because people single-mindedly think of the right Dharma and goodness that they are not reborn in the next world?
NÄgasena said:
It is because people single-mindedly think of the right Dharma, think of goodness, wisdom, and other good things that they are not reborn in the next world.
The king said:
When people single-mindedly think of the right Dharma and goodness and wisdom, are the meanings of these two things the same?
NÄgasena said:
Their meanings are different and not the same.
The king asked NÄgasena:
Do cattle, horses, and the six domestic animals have wisdom or not?
NÄsa said:
Cattle, horses, and the six domestic animals each have their own intelligence, but their minds are not the same.
NÄsa said:
Has the king ever seen a wheat harvester?
With the left hand holding the wheat, and with the right hand cutting it.
NÄsa said:
A wise person cuts off desires, just like harvesting wheat.
The king said:
Excellent!
The king asked NÄsa again:
What are the other good things?
NÄsa said:
Sincerity, filial piety, diligence, mindfulness of goodness, single-mindedness, and wisdom are good things.
The king said:
What is sincerity?
NÄsa said:

The faithful have no more doubts. They believe in the Buddha, the Buddha's sutras and Dharma, the Sangha of monks, the arhats, this world, the next world, filial piety towards parents, that doing good brings good, and that doing evil brings evil.
Having faith, one's later thoughts become pure, and one then departs from the five evils.
What are the five evils?
First, lust, second, anger, third, sleep, fourth, play, and fifth, doubt.
If one does not depart from these five evils, the mind is unstable;
if one departs from these five evils, the mind becomes pure.
NÄgasena said:
It is like a king crossing a river in a chariot drawn by horses, causing the water to become turbid.
After crossing, the king becomes thirsty and wants to drink the water.
The king has a clear water pearl, which, when placed in water, makes the water clear, so that the king can drink the clear water.
NÄsa said:
The human mind has evil, like turbid water.
The Buddha's disciples attain the way of transcending birth and death, and their minds become pure, like the clear water of the pearl.
People remove all evil, and their sincerity and purity are like the bright moon pearl.
The king said:
Excellent, excellent!
The king asked:
What is it like for a person to be diligent and sincere?
NÄsa said:

The Buddha's disciples, when they see each other, remove all evil thoughts from within. Some attain the stage of stream-enterer, some attain the stage of once-returner, some attain the stage of non-returner, some attain the stage of arhatship, and some, inspired by each other, practice sincerity and faith, and all attain the way of transcending the world.
NÄsa said:
It is like a great rain on a mountain, the water flowing down vast, and people on both sides do not know the depth of the water, fearing to cross.

If there is a person coming from afar, looking at the water, they secretly know the width, narrowness, depth, and shallowness of the water, and knowing their own strength, they can enter the water and then cross over.
The people on both sides then follow their example and are also able to cross.

The Buddha's disciples are also like this. Seeing that the previous person has attained the mind of purity, and attained the paths of stream-entry, once-returning, non-returning, and arhatship, all come from the good mind and diligent practice.
The Buddha's sutras say:
If a person has a sincere and faithful mind, they can attain liberation from the world themselves.
If an ascetic can restrain and stop the five desires and know the suffering of the body, they will be able to attain liberation from the world.
People all attain their virtue and morality through wisdom.
The king said:
Excellent, excellent!
The king said:
What is filial obedience?
NÄgasena said:
All goodness is for the sake of filial piety.
The thirty-seven chapters of the sutra all have filial piety as their basis.
The king said:
What are the thirty-seven chapters of the sutra?
NÄgasena said:

There are the four foundations of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of enlightenment, and the eightfold noble path.
The king asked NÄgasena again:
What are the four foundations of mindfulness?
NÄgasena replied to the king:
The Buddha said that the first is mindfulness of the body, the second is mindfulness of feelings, the third is mindfulness of the mind, and the fourth is mindfulness of dharmas.
These are the four foundations of mindfulness.
The king said again:
What are the four right efforts?
NÄgasena said:
The Buddha said that it is to discern and stop the four things and not think of them again, which are the four right efforts.
By attaining the four intentions, one can naturally attain the four bases of supernatural power.
The king asked again:
What are the four bases of supernatural power?
NÄgasena said:
First, the eyes can see through; second, the ears can hear through; third, one can know what others are thinking in their hearts; fourth, the body can fly.
These are the four bases of supernatural power.
The king asked again:
What are the five faculties?
NÄgasena said:

First, when the eyes see good or bad colors, the mind does not crave them; this is a faculty. Second, when the ears hear good sounds or slander, the mind does not crave them; this is a faculty. Third, when the nose smells fragrances or foul odors, the mind does not crave them; this is a faculty. Fourth, when the mouth tastes delicious flavors or bitter flavors, the mind does not crave them; this is a faculty. Fifth, when the body feels smoothness, the mind is not delighted, and when the body feels coarseness, the mind is not averse; this is a faculty. These are the five faculties.
The king asked again:
What are the five powers?
NÄgasena said:

The first is the ability to control the eyes, the second is the ability to control the ears, the third is the ability to control the nose, the fourth is the ability to control the mouth, and the fifth is the ability to control the body, preventing the mind from falling into them. These are the five powers.
The king asked again:
What are the seven factors of awakening?
NÄgasena said:

The first is the factor of mindfulness, the second is the factor of investigation of phenomena, the third is the factor of energy, the fourth is the factor of joy, the fifth is the factor of tranquility, the sixth is the factor of concentration, and the seventh is the factor of equanimity.
These are the seven factors of awakening.
The king asked again:
What are the eightfold noble path?
NÄgasena said:

The first is right view, the second is right thought, the third is right speech, the fourth is right action, the fifth is right livelihood, the sixth is right effort, the seventh is right mindfulness, and the eighth is right concentration.
These are the eightfold noble path.
All these thirty-seven factors of enlightenment are based on filial obedience.
NÄsa said:
Ordinary people carry heavy burdens far away and achieve something, all by relying on the earth. The five grains, trees, and grasses that depend on the sky in the world all grow from the earth.
NÄsa said:
It is like a master craftsman who wants to build a great city. He must first measure and lay the foundation before he can build the city.
NÄsa said:
It is like an entertainer who wants to perform. He must first clear the ground and level it before he can perform.

The Buddha's disciples who seek the Way should first practice the sutras and precepts, contemplate goodness, understand suffering, and then abandon all desires and attachments, and contemplate the eightfold noble path.
The king said:
What should be used to abandon all desires and attachments?
NÄsa said:
Single-mindedly contemplate the Way, and desires and attachments will naturally disappear.
The king said:
Excellent, excellent!
The king asked again:
What is meant by diligence?
NÄsa said:
Upholding goodness and assisting goodness is called diligence.
NÄgasena said:
It is like a wall about to collapse, supporting it from the side;
A house about to collapse, also supporting it.
This is diligence.
NÄgasena said:
It is like a king sending troops to attack, the troops being weak and about to be defeated, the king sends more troops to assist them, and the troops then win.
People have various evils, like when the troops are weak;
People uphold good thoughts to eliminate evil thoughts, like when the king increases troops and wins.
Upholding the five good thoughts to eliminate the five evil thoughts, like winning in battle.
This is diligence assisting goodness.
It is like this.
NÄgasena said:
What diligence assists leads people to the good path, and they attain the path of transcendence without returning.
The king said:
Excellent!
The king asked again:
What do you mean by 'the mind should always think of good things'?
NÄgasena said:
It is like a person who takes flowers of different kinds and strings them together with thread, so that the wind cannot scatter them.
NÄgasena continued:
It is like a royal storekeeper who knows the quantity of gold, silver, pearls, jade, and precious treasures in the king's treasury.

When a practitioner wishes to attain the Way, they contemplate the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, it is like this, this is precisely what is meant by 'always thinking of the Way to liberation.'

People have the intention of the Way, and therefore know good and evil, know what should be done and what should not be done, distinguish right from wrong, and after self-reflection, they abandon evil and pursue goodness.
NÄgasena said:
It is like a king having a gatekeeper who knows whom the king respects and whom the king does not respect, knows who benefits the king and who does not benefit the king.

The gatekeeper knows who the king respects and who benefits the king, and lets them in. He knows who the king does not respect and who does not benefit the king, and the gatekeeper does not let them in.
NÄsa said:
People's minds are also like this. The good ones should be let in, and the bad ones should not be let in.
Guarding the mind and controlling the thoughts are also like this.
NÄsa said in the sutra:
People should firmly guard their minds and the six desires in their bodies. Holding the mind firmly and guarding it, they will have a time of transcending the world.
The king said:
Excellent, excellent!
The king asked NÄsa:
What is meant by unifying the mind?
NÄsa said:
Among all wholesome states, having a single mind is the foremost. If a person can unify their mind, all wholesome states will follow it.
NÄsa said:
It is like a building that must rely on something, all good deeds are based on a single mind.
NÄgasena said:
It is like when a king leads the four types of troops on an expedition to fight, the elephant troops, horse troops, chariot troops, and infantry all guide the king in front and behind.
The Buddha's various sutras, precepts, and other good deeds all follow a single mind, which is also like the troops.
NÄgasena spoke the sutra and said:
Among all good deeds, a single mind is the root. There are many people who study the path, all of whom should first return to a single mind.
The body of a person passes through birth and death like water flowing downstream, following each other before and after without a moment of rest.
The king said:
Excellent!
The king asked again:
What is wisdom?
NÄgasena said:
I have already said before that a person has wisdom, can cut off all doubts, and clarify all good things, this is wisdom.
NÄgasena said:
It is like bringing a lamp into a dark room - as soon as the lamp enters the room, the darkness disappears and it becomes bright by itself.
A person who has wisdom is like the light of a lamp.
NÄsa said:
It is like a person holding a sharp knife to cut wood.
A person who has wisdom can cut off all evils, like a sharp knife.
NÄsa said:
Among people in the world, wisdom is the most important.
A person who has wisdom can attain liberation from the suffering of birth and death.
The king said:
Excellent!
The king said:
The various different sutras that NÄsa has spoken of before and after, do they all aim to eliminate all evils?
NÄsa said:
Yes.
The various good things spoken of in the Buddha's sutras all aim to eliminate all evils.
NÄsa said:
It is like when a king dispatches the four types of troops to fight, although they engage in battle, when they first set out, their intention is only to attack the enemy.
The various good deeds taught in the Buddha's sutras are only intended to help attack and remove all evil.
The king said:
Excellent, excellent!
NÄgasena's explanation of the sutras is wonderful.
The king asked NÄgasena again:
After a person dies and goes to the good or evil paths, does the spirit continue to be reborn in the same body?
Or is it reborn in a different body?
NÄgasena said:
It is neither the same as the old body, nor is it separate from the old body.
NÄgasena then asked:
When the king was a child and being breastfed, was the body at that time the same as the body when he grew up?
The king said:
The body when I was a child was different.
NÄgasena said:
When a person is in the mother's womb, from when the embryo first follows the essence to when the essence becomes turbid, is it the same as the original essence?
It is different.
Is the flesh and bones the same as the essence?
No, they are different.
Is the essence at birth the same as when one is a few years old?
No, they are different.
When a person learns to write, can someone else take over their skill?
The king said:
They cannot take over the skill.
NÄgasena said:
If a person commits an offense and is guilty, can an innocent person be found to take their place?
The king said:
No, that cannot be done.
NÄgasena used the spirit and the law of offenses to speak to the king, but the king did not understand. The king then said:
If someone asks NÄgasena, how does NÄgasena understand it?
NÄgasena said:
My body is still the same body from when I was young. From small to large, it is the same body.
The large and small bodies are contained in one body, nourished by this life.
NÄgasena asked the king, saying:
It's like a person lighting a lamp, would it last until dawn?
The king said:
The lamp oil would last until dawn.
NÄgasena said:
Is the wick of the lamp the same fire that lasted through the night?ğŸ”½Is it the same fire that lasted through midnight?
Is it the same fire that lasted until dawn?
The king said:
It is not the same fire.
NÄgasena said:
From the night until midnight, did you light another lamp?
Did you light another lamp towards dawn?
The king said:
I did not get up in the middle of the night to light another lamp, the same wick of fire lasted until dawn.
NÄgasena said:
The continuation of a person's spirit is also like this, one goes and one comes.

From the time a person is born from the spirit until old age and death, the spirit goes on to the next life, and the continuity of transmigration continues. This is not the old spirit, nor is it the new spirit.
After a person dies, the spirit goes on to the next life.
NÄgasena said:
For example, milk turns into curd, and the cream on top of the curd is boiled to make ghee. Can the ghee be taken and the cream on top of the curd be called milk again?
Is the person's statement usable?
The king said:
His statement is unusable.
NÄgasena said:
The person's spirit turns from milk to curd, from curd to cream, and from cream to ghee.

The person's spirit is also like this. It is born from the spirit, from birth to growth, from growth to old age, and from old age to death. After death, the spirit will receive life again. When one body dies, it will receive another body.
It is like two masters passing on to each other.
The king said:
Excellent, excellent!
The king asked Ä€nanda again:
If a person is not reborn in the next life, can they know it themselves?
Ä€nanda said:
Yes.
There are those who can know it themselves.
The king said:
How do they know it?
Ä€nanda said:
That person knows they have no affection, no greed, and no evil thoughts, and therefore they know they will not be reborn in the next life.
Ä€nanda asked the king:

Suppose a farmer plows the fields, plants grains, and harvests a lot, storing it in the granary. In the following year, he does not plow or plant again, but relies on the grains in the granary to eat.
Would that farmer still expect to get new grains?
The king said:
He would have nothing more to expect.
Ä€nanda said:
How does that farmer know he will not get more grains?
The king said:
The farmer no longer plows or plants, so he has nothing to look forward to.
NÄgasena said:

Attaining the Way is also like this. One knows for oneself that one has abandoned love and hate, suffering and joy, and has no greedy mind. Therefore, one knows for oneself that one will not be reborn in the next world.
The king said again:
If a person is not reborn in the next world, is he now any different in wisdom from ordinary people?
NÄgasena said:
Yes.
He has wisdom that is different from ordinary people.
The king said:
Can he be said to have insight?
NÄgasena said:
Yes.
He has insight.
The king said:
Is there a difference between wisdom and insight?
NÄgasena said:
Wisdom and insight are the same.
The king said:
Does one who has wisdom and insight know all ten thousand things?
Are there any that he does not know?ğŸ”½NÄgasena said:
Yes.
Human wisdom has its limits and its limitations.
The king said:
What are the limits and limitations of wisdom?
NÄgasena said:
What a person has not learned before, they cannot know before.
What a person has learned before, they can know before.
The wise see that people and all things will eventually return to emptiness and lose their independence.
The things that people crave and enjoy are all the roots of suffering, and from this suffering arises.
The wise know that impermanence leads to failure, and this wisdom is different from that of ordinary people.
The king asked:
Where are the wisdom and foolishness of a person located?
NÄgasena said:
When a person has wisdom, all foolishness disappears by itself.
NÄgasena said:
It is like a person holding a lamp and entering a dark room, the room becomes bright and the darkness disappears immediately.
Wisdom is like this. If a person has wisdom, all foolishness and ignorance will be completely eliminated.
The king said:
Where is the wisdom of a person now?
NÄgasena said:
After a person practices wisdom, the wisdom is then eliminated. It is because of what wisdom has done that it is done.
NÄgasena said:
It is like a person writing on a fire at night. When the fire goes out, the writing remains.
The wise are like this. After accomplishing something, the wisdom is then eliminated, but what was done remains.
The king said:
After wisdom has accomplished something and then eliminated itself, what does this mean?
NÄgasena said:
It is like a person preparing for a fire, in advance making five jars of water as a precaution against fire.
If there is a fire, that person uses the five jars of water to extinguish the fire.
After the fire is extinguished, would the person who saved the fire still expect to get the intact jars back for household use?
The king said:
If the person no longer expects, and the jar breaks and the fire goes out, would they still expect the jar?
NÄgasena said:
The practitioner uses the five wholesome thoughts to eliminate all evils, which is also like the water in the jar extinguishing the fire.
The king said:
What are the five wholesome [thoughts]?
NÄgasena said:

First, believing in good and evil; second, not violating the scriptures and precepts; third, diligence; fourth, having wisdom and mindfulness of good; fifth, single-mindedly contemplating the Way. These are the five wholesome [thoughts].

If a person is able to uphold and practice these five wholesome [thoughts], they will attain wisdom, understand that the body and all things are impermanent, understand suffering and lack of autonomy, and understand emptiness and non-existence.
NÄgasena said:
It is like a doctor who takes five kinds of medicine to the patient's home and gives the medicine to the patient.
If the patient drinks the medicine and is cured, would the doctor still expect to get the old medicine and go treat another person?
The king said:
I no longer hope to obtain the old medicine.
NÄgasena said:
The five kinds of medicine are like the five kinds of good wisdom.
The doctor is like one who seeks the path.
The illness is like the various evils.
Foolishness is like a sick person.
One who attains the path and crosses over the world is like a person whose illness is cured.
Wisdom is what enables a person to cross over to the path of the world;
Once a person has attained the path, wisdom also disappears by itself.
NÄgasena said:
It is like a strong warrior who goes forth holding a bow and arrows, and shoots five arrows at the enemy to win. Would he still hope for the arrows to return?
The king said:
I would not hope for the arrows to return.
NÄgasena said:
The five arrows are the five kinds of wisdom of a person.
A wise person attains the path through wisdom, just as a strong warrior wins over the enemy.
The various evils are like the various evils.
The practitioner upholds the five wholesome thoughts to extinguish all evils, and all evils are extinguished, and wholesome wisdom is then born.
People attain liberation through wholesome wisdom, and the Way always abides without extinction.
The king said:
Excellent!
The king said:
If a person attains the Way and is not reborn in the next world, will they still suffer again in the future?
NÄgasena said:
Some will suffer again, while others will not suffer again.
The king said:
Why will some suffer again and others not?
NÄgasena said:
The body will suffer again, but the mind and thoughts will not suffer again.
The king said:
Why will the body suffer again and the mind and thoughts not?
NÄgasena said:
The reason the body will suffer again is because the body is still present and will suffer again;
The mind and thoughts abandon all evils and have no desires, so they will not suffer again.
The king said:
If a person who has attained the Way cannot escape bodily suffering, is this not because they have not yet attained the Way to Nirvana?
The king said:
A person who has attained the Way has no attachments, and their mind is at ease even in bodily suffering. What is the use of attaining the Way?
The king said:
If a person has already attained the Way, what else is there to wait for?
Nagasena said:
It is like a fruit that is not ripe yet, one cannot force it to ripen;
when it is ripe, there is nothing more to wait for.
Nagasena said:
What you have just said, Your Majesty, is similar to what the Buddha said. The Buddha said:
'I do not seek death, nor do I seek life. I only wait for the right time, and when the time comes, I will depart.'
The king said:
Excellent, excellent!
